CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: For comparison , the image of P7 : PC61BM blend showed coarser domains with a rougher surface , as the films were prepared from chloroform unlike other the blends . A new series of PBDTT-DPP-TPD random terpolymers containing two different electron - deficient units ( DPP and TPD ) were synthesized to produce polymers with complementary and broad light absorption from 400 to 900 nm. Through the variation of DPP to TPD composition in the polymers , we successfully tuned the frontier energy levels and illustrated the benefits of this approach in relation to PSC device performance. The optimal ratio of 75 : 25 between DPP and TPD in the random terpolymers enhanced the efficiency of P3 : PC71BM , exhibiting 6.33% due to improved light absorption and thus a J SC value higher than 16 mA / cm^2. In contrast , P5 and P6 with higher TPD contents of 75 and 90% , respectively , exhibited PCE values of 2-3 % , which are significantly lower than those observed for P1 and P7. We found that the optical and electrochemical properties of the polymers could not solely explain this nonlinear compositional dependence. Therefore , we developed a quantitative understanding of the polymer packing structure and the electrical properties using GIXS and DFT , respectively. The DFT calculation results revealed that incorporation of two electron - deficient units changes the electron distribution in the polymer backbone , thus affecting the charge transfer in the PSCs. Consequently , these findings suggest that the design and synthesis of new random terpolymers is a promising way to broaden the absorption of their parent polymers and that optimization of the composition of random terpolymers is critically important to maximize the PSC performance. ■ ASSOCIATED CONTENT * S Supporting Information Materials and methods , detailed experimental procedures , and additional data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. Corresponding Author *E - mail : bumjoonkim @ kaist.ac.kr ( B.J.K. ) .

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph. We will present them in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Here are the valid entities:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PC61BM |
| P7 |
| PBDTT-DPP-TPD |
| P3 |
| PC71BM |
| P5 |
| P6 |

Note that we have listed the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Now, let's go through each property name and explain why it is included in the table:

1. P7: This is the name of the image shown in the paragraph, which is a comparison of the film prepared from chloroform (P7) and other blends.
2. PC61BM: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, which is a blend of PC61BM and chloroform.
3. PBDTT-DPP-TPD: This is the name of a new series of random terpolymers synthesized in the study, which contains two different electron-deficient units (DPP and TPD).
4. DPP: This is one of the electron-deficient units present in the random terpolymers.
5. TPD: This is the other electron-deficient unit present in the random terpolymers.
6. P3: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, which is a blend of PBDTT-DPP-TPD and PC71BM.
7. PC71BM: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, which is a blend of PC61BM and chloroform.
8. P1: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, whose composition is not specified in the paragraph.
9. P5: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, whose composition is not specified in the paragraph.
10. P6: This is the name of a polymer used in the study, whose composition is not specified in the paragraph.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: For comparison , the image of P7 : PC61BM blend showed coarser domains with a rougher surface , as the films were prepared from chloroform unlike other the blends . A new series of PBDTT-DPP-TPD random terpolymers containing two different electron - deficient units ( DPP and TPD ) were synthesized to produce polymers with complementary and broad light absorption from 400 to 900 nm. Through the variation of DPP to TPD composition in the polymers , we successfully tuned the frontier energy levels and illustrated the benefits of this approach in relation to PSC device performance. The optimal ratio of 75 : 25 between DPP and TPD in the random terpolymers enhanced the efficiency of P3 : PC71BM , exhibiting 6.33% due to improved light absorption and thus a J SC value higher than 16 mA / cm^2. In contrast , P5 and P6 with higher TPD contents of 75 and 90% , respectively , exhibited PCE values of 2-3 % , which are significantly lower than those observed for P1 and P7. We found that the optical and electrochemical properties of the polymers could not solely explain this nonlinear compositional dependence. Therefore , we developed a quantitative understanding of the polymer packing structure and the electrical properties using GIXS and DFT , respectively. The DFT calculation results revealed that incorporation of two electron - deficient units changes the electron distribution in the polymer backbone , thus affecting the charge transfer in the PSCs. Consequently , these findings suggest that the design and synthesis of new random terpolymers is a promising way to broaden the absorption of their parent polymers and that optimization of the composition of random terpolymers is critically important to maximize the PSC performance. ■ ASSOCIATED CONTENT * S Supporting Information Materials and methods , detailed experimental procedures , and additional data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. Corresponding Author *E - mail : bumjoonkim @ kaist.ac.kr ( B.J.K. ) .

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the values of material properties in the given paragraph. We will present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Here is the table:

| Property Value |
| --- |
| P7 |
| PC61BM |
| chloroform |
| DPP |
| TPD |
| 75 : 25 |
| 6.33% |
| 16 mA/cm^2 |
| 2-3% |
| PCE |
| GIXS |
| DFT |
| electron - deficient units |
| electron distribution |
| charge transfer |
| polymer packing structure |
| electrical properties |

Explanation:

1. P7: This is the name of the image shown in the paragraph.
2. PC61BM: This is the name of the blend of polymers used in the experiment.
3. Chloroform: This is the solvent used to prepare the films.
4. DPP: This is one of the electron-deficient units present in the random terpolymers.
5. TPD: This is another electron-deficient unit present in the random terpolymers.
6. 75 : 25: This is the ratio of DPP to TPD in the optimal random terpolymer.
7. 6.33%: This is the percentage of efficiency improvement observed for the optimal random terpolymer.
8. 16 mA/cm^2: This is the improved current density observed for the optimal random terpolymer.
9. 2-3%: This is the range of PCE values observed for the other random terpolymers with higher TPD contents.
10. PCE: This stands for Power Conversion Efficiency.
11. GIXS: This stands for Grazing Incidence X-ray Spectroscopy.
12. DFT: This stands for Density Functional Theory.
13. Electron-deficient units: These are units with a deficiency of electrons in their molecular structure.
14. Electron distribution: This refers to the distribution of electrons within the polymer backbone.
15. Charge transfer: This refers to the transfer of electrons between the polymer and the electrode in a PSC.
16. Polymer packing structure: This refers to the arrangement of the polymer chains in the bulk material.
17. Electrical properties: This refers to the properties of the polymer that affect its electrical conductivity and other related properties.
